reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just finished the first world of 'Parcel' and I have to say I'm impressed. The puzzle mechnic is to pick up and carry a yellow cube (I'm assuming your parcel, you clever developers you) and bring it with you to the exit.

This is where the game gets interesting, by placing, pushing and pulling your parcel to block lasers and make your way to the exit. It's challenging in a way I want my puzzle games to be. Just enough but you feel satisfaction when you complete a puzzle.

It seems theres a ton of content already, a puzzle creation toolset, and a work in progress story.

Though the $9.99 price tag may be a bit much for some people to take a blind leap into, however, I think it's worth it. There's not to many well made puzzle games out there.

With active developers and community input I could see this turning into a real gem of a puzzle game with the endless possibilities with user created content.

Here's my First Look Video of the First World Check it out! ( May Still Be Uploading)

https://youtu.be/6jmAC2fxUp4

For more reviews and bi-weekly podcast about Early Access and Indie games checkout www.EarlyAccessPodcast.com
voteText: 26 of 32 people (81%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You know that grey mass of fat between your ears? Yes, I am talking about your brain. Your are going to need that, so take it with you when you dive into the fantastic puzzles of parcel. Dark, yet colorful atmosphere allows you to stay as long as you like and after a while game ramps up the difficulty so, that you constantly stay properly challenged.

Every cleared level feels like a huge victory, althought they might seem a bit intimidating at start.

Dataspheres have also proven to be interesting in two ways. Getting them is an additional challenge, and after reading some of them it seems like their content properly justifies the extra effort required to get them. Things that they hint or reveal about parcels dark world are both entertaining and puzzling in their own way.

All in all this game deserves to be played. For an early access game this seems very well finished and polished, and there is no lack of content!

I warmly recommend!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Watch me play this game, and at the end of the video I play alongside my son where we work together to try and conquer a couple of levels:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3JaEp46HzXg

Okay, at first I was a little hesitant.  There were no videos or reviews up for many hours, and this game seemed perhaps a little steep.. and I've been burned on some of these Indie puzzle games already.  But I took the leap anyhow.

..And I am happy that I did.

This game is not just great, it is absolutely brilliant.  And a ton of fun to play as well!

Your job is to get past laser beams using the well thought out level designs with your single block in hand.  Along the route from where you start to where you must get to, you'll need to use your block by placing, pulling, or pushing it to block laser beams that obstruct you.  Death is not possible in this game, it simply won't allow you to step into places you can't go.  Sounds simple.  But as the levels quickly get more cleverly designed, you'll need to actually use your brain power for something besides a just a goop of grey matter sitting idle between your ears.

The brilliance in the game mechanics, well designed levels, fluid controls, and nice graphics makes for one of the most satisfying and fun puzzle games that I have played in years.

Over 120 puzzles already in early access?  And the ability to create your own, share them, and play other players levels as well?  OMG.  Add in the ability to play local co-op on a single computer as I did in the video with my son, and you have yourself a little Indie gem here.  This game is the reason I take chances on Indie" games.  This game is easily one of the best puzzles games I have ever played.  ...Enough said.

Is it worth your $10 USD?  ...If you really need my answer after reading this far
date: you might wanna get better at "thinking" if you do buy this game.  You'll need to increase your thinking power if you have to ask me that after reading this review this far or watching my video!  :-)\n\nTo the developers who are Polar Bunny Ltd:  Thank you much for this masterpiece of a game!  I love it and look forward to seeing this game as it develops further and any future games you guys design.  Fantastic job
voteText: true

reviewText:
First impression:
It's a Sokoban-style puzzle game with a companion cube and lasers.

And yeah, we've seen lots of box pushing games, and laser puzzle games, but none where you needed to pack up your box at the end (it's not enough to just reach the exit), and none that had co-op play (you can switch between up to 4 characters if you play alone), and of course this one also has gamepad support.

You get 4 different box pushers: the first one, the postman, can just pick the parcel up and set it down. The next one is magentic and can pull it (but not push), and the third one can only use switches that can block and unblock pathways and those robots with lasers. I haven't gotten to the fourth one yet.
So these are different skills, and since the objective is not only to get the box where it needs to go, but all of these toons as well, it can get a little hairy. It is a lot of fun to play together, because you're continuously helping each other out. Most levels have at least two characters, those that have only one are usually quick.

The mechanics are simple, yet the last level we played took us half an hour - we think we did half of the levels, but the game says we're 25% done.

Push boxes with a friend! I'm sold. Parcel turned out to be a very accessible, very enjoyable brain twister.

reviewText: I've got to say, this is the best $0.49 I've ever spent.  To get a Community Achievement, I just needed a throw-away type of game.  So, I went looking for the cheapest game with Trading Cards and Workshop support that I could find.  That game was Parcel" (on sale).  I am agog.  Honestly
date: this is one of the best games I've played.  In concept
recommended: it's simple.  Over the course of the game
hoursPlayed: you unlock six characters (each with a special ability).  You've got to move some subset of those characters (and perhaps pick up a "data sphere" (which give you the storyline) along the way) to their own ending positions.  It's not complex.  But
voteText: by the end of the game
helpfulPercent: it becomes very challenging to do.  In fact
votesHelpful: the game makes you wonder about your own intelligence:  I can't count the number of times I got stuck (and confirmed my stuckedness repeatedly in my own head)
votesTotal: gone off to view a walkthrough
votesFunny: only to realize I'd missed something simple.  It's embarrassing.  It took me 42.7 hours of very interesting gameplay to finish the game with 100% Achievements.  So
commentsCount: not only do I recommend the game at the ridiculously low price I found it at
column16: I also recommend it at its full list price.\n\nI do have some issues with the game.  Most of them fall in the "wish the UI were a bit different" category.  But
column17: the one gameplay issue I have is that the difficulty progression isn't smooth.  In general
column18: the later levels tend to be harder than the earlier ones.  But
column20: the difficulty might oscillate between easy and hard without reason.  Of course
column21: it's very possible that a level I found to be challenging might be easy for someone else (and vice-versa).  So
column22: I'm not sure if that's a gameplay issue or an individual cognition issue.\n\nAnyway
column23: some of my UI change wishlist items are:\n\n- It would be nice if each level kept the level number
column25: and active character's name on screen during play.\n- The use of the above items should be consistent between Achievements
column28: it's a bit confusing knowing what's what because each area refers to objects differently.\n- There needs to be more hand-holding right at the beginning until you realize what you're supposed to do.\n- On a couple of levels
column29: for some reason the lighting bleeds through around the characters and/or their ending point beacons.  It makes it very difficult to see who's who and where they're supposed to go.\n- The "We Don't Need Another Hero" Achievement requires you to NOT even finish the tutorial for one of the characters until after you finish all the levels possible to complete without him.  Yet
column30: the Tutorial level for another character you need before getting that Achievement uses that missing character.\n- The last several Achievements don't pop up when you meet their requirements.  Instead
column31: you have to repeat the "Boss' Room" level a second time to get the pop-ups.\n\nAgain
column32: all of the above are minor and I highly recommend the game."

reviewText: Parcel is a great puzzle game that builds from incredible simplicity into a surprising amount of depth. Its great to see indie developers like this put out a solid product that really captures the passion they put into it. This is the kind of game that really shines with steam broadcasting too, the minor delay not being an obstacle in allowing you and a friend to work together in analyzing and deconstructing each puzzle and having a rewarding time doing it.\n\nI hope Polar Bunny's passion is rewarded with this but I can see this game falling through the cracks for a lot of people. If you're checking it out, don't let it fall through for you.
voteText: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Played this game over a friends house.  A great thing about this game is that it provides controller support, so if you have multiple controllers and friends to play with, you can play this game with multiple people (up to 4).

The number of people that can play is based on the level, but once you unlock the third character, most levels are usually at least 3 players.

Now in terms of enjoyment in the game, it all boils down to this.  Do you enjoy challenging puzzle games?  Do your friends like puzzle games?  Do you enjoy your friends?  Regardless of the answer for the last question, this game is for you, as it can be used as a great griefing engine if you wanna trap them in a 1x1 square surrounded on all sides by laser spiders.

Overall, I highly recommend this game for anyone looking for a fun multiplayer puzzle game at a great price. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Some bits of this game are clearly early access - the menus, the editor, and there are a few oddities. Despite this - as long as there are no major regressions - I can already recommend this. Why? Because the characters really come together.

Like your standard puzzle game, each character has one simple mechanic that is pushed to the limit by each puzzle. However, this game has 4 (or so) of these characters. Individually, with the various laser set-pieces, they can be part of  pretty darn challenging puzzles. Combined, they can be made into extremely hard puzzles... with extremely satisfying solutions. Several of the built in puzzles have brilliant aha" moments
date: which is key to a good puzzle game.\n\nThe gameplay is rock solid - not a single gameplay glitch. There are a few visual bugs and grammar issues - and as mentioned before
recommended: the menus still feel shaky. The worst part of the menus is that a whole set of "special place" levels are hidden behind an extremely unobtrusive button. A "switch space"
hoursPlayed: taking inspiration from Super Meat Boy's light/dark modes would work better
voteText: I think.\n\nI've played through a large number of puzzles (I am pleasantly stuck on some of them)
helpfulPercent: yet there are still a lot more to go. I've got 5 hours on the clock with maybe half the puzzles solved.\n\nWhile the editor is clearly unfinished
votesHelpful: and filled with usability issues and weird behavior
votesTotal: it "does the job". I wouldn't want to design a level's visuals in it
votesFunny: but hammering out the logic is easy enough and lets you build your own mind bending puzzles
commentsCount: if you feel inspired. (I was)\n\nThe sound effects
column16: visuals and animations are nice. Some of the built in levels look bleached out from overlighting
column17: beyond the pleasant cacphony of neon
column18: but generally everything is both functional and pleasant to look at. There are a couple of visual problems in levels which make them unnecessarily hard to solve
column19: I want to see those fixed before I'd recommend this without the early access tag (unlit squares and visually obstructed squares). The music is nothing to write home about
column20: but it's not offensive and you can mute it.\n\nI bought it for full price
column21: and I'm extremely happy with it. I look forward to solving more
column22: and to horrible people creating insanely hard community levels.\n\nDisclosure: I know the company behind Parcel personally. Still
column23: I wouldn't sacrifice impartiality for any of them. ^_^"

reviewText: Parcel is an engaging puzzle game, with nice graphics and soundtrack. Stages are usually small, but don't be fooled by the look of them, many will require an astonishing amount of moves to beat. You'll be switching back and forth between different characters on the field, each one with a distincting and unique ability, trying to figure out how to navigate the stage in order to put every one of your little helpers on its own extraction tile at the end of the struggle. What do you have to watch out for? Laser beams of course!! New characters will be introduced along the way, each with an even more game-changing ability compared to the previous one, increasing manyfold the variety of gameplay every time. Not gonna lie to you, you'll fail many times before eventually getting it right, we both know that's how it's supposed to be.\n\nFor an additional challange, go right away for the 'We don't need another hero' achievement ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally, a game that is very challenging.. The last level of the first floor, I actually played with my mouth open, dazzled by the puzzle(even though some of you may think this was easy).. But soon I learned how Parcel works (atleast with one character but as they introduce more, I have to learn it again and again; that's a good thing though), I can't wait to play more of this.

The characters are lovely, and the co-op possibility is attracting, I hope I had someone to play with (:forever alone).
Although, my roommate did come to my room to ask something, and stayed watching me play for a while.

The story is intriguing.. I need to know who is this yellow future postman? What is he delivering.. for who? And the most important question: WHAT'S IN THE PARCEL???

It's a total 5/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The bright and blocky environment invites players of all demographics to get their daily mental exercise, but the eye-candy graphics should not be mistaken for an easy ride. Parcel quickly ups the difficulty by introducing new mechanics and increasing the number of actors on screen. The simple rules grow into an amazing array of brain-twisting challenges, all just as complex as they need to be.

Parcel is already seeping with content in its early release and the included level editor ensures entertainment for ages. Absolutely worth the purchase!

reviewText:
I got this game after using a discount voucher - and for the money I paid I was very impressed.

Some of the puzzles in this game a very challenging, but it is very satisfying when you can work out the solutions.

A couple of minor negatives for this game - after unlocking the 6th character that smashes blocks, I found the smashing animation slowed the frame rate right down before going back to normal after the animation is complete. I have a mid-level PC but the rest of the game runs perfectly smoothly.

Also, if you restart a level that you have smashed blocks in - the blocks spawn back but only as black blocks, rather than with the textures they originally had.

All in all despite these minor issues, I fully enjoyed the challenge this game provided and would easily recommend this.

reviewText: Parcel is... okay. Great graphics, cool characters, neat concept & gimmicks, but the gameplay falls very short. My main complaint about this game is how easy it is to get WAY off track when solving a puzzle. Now keep in mind, you are able to make a save state" and reload with the backspace key to where you left off if you make a mistake
date: but the questionable level design allows the player to make a lengthy set of moves
recommended: only for it to fail completely when they realize one wrong action completely ruined their meticulous strategy
hoursPlayed: and they have to start from the beginning anyway. It's not a good feeling
voteText: and it severely demotivates the player from wanting to continue. One thing I would suggest instead of having this faulty save state option is to simply take back one move every time the player hits the backspace key (or alternatively press and hold backspace to rewind the play field back to where you want it); that alone could save a ton of headaches and frustration later on in the game.\n\nThat being said though
helpfulPercent: I still enjoy the core concept this game brought. I like the idea of having all of these characters each with unique abilities that the others don't have
votesHelpful: I just wish there was more flexibility with the solutions. In a good puzzle game like Portal 2 there are more often then not multiple solutions and/or routes to approaching a solution. But for this game you are expected to make a very specific and meticulous set of moves from start to finish that would not be too far off from trying to split an atom. I've always hated puzzle games that go this route
votesTotal: and it is NOT good game design.\n\nOverall just an okay game
votesFunny: but it does have potential. It's up to the developers whether or not they feel this game could benefit from making improvements."

reviewText: Overall 7/10. Recommended for people who like puzzle games with a high difficulty and a high tolerance for frustration. Yellow guy = carries a box
recommended: Green Guy = toggles barriers (for the box)
hoursPlayed: Blue guy = swaps characters (and the box)
voteText: Orange guy = jumps through barriers (including the box)
helpfulPercent: Purple guy = smashes walls (but not the box). You get TONS of levels
votesTotal: and the puzzles are very difficult so you'll get your money's worth based on time. It looks like a dinky little game but it's not (I spent 30 hours). There's also little collectibles throughout the game
commentsCount: but it's the only little bit of story there is. The cons are the color scheme
column16: which looks like someone turned the constrast and saturation up to maximum
column17: so much that it's hard to see the characters. Also
column18: the 3/4 view at times blocked accessible pathways and made them look inaccessible. There's also a limit on the number of times you can use certain powers
column19: which means that even if you have a fantastic

column22: sometimes with an entirely different plan. There's only one "right" solution
column23: and they even set up the characters in such a way that you never have leftover moves. (Like blocking in the only character that can act first

column26: and overall there were only about 12 of about 80-100 puzzles or so (I'm too lazy to count) that I couldn't finish or needed a hint on. (Also

reviewText:
I used to play Sokoban on my gameboy all the time. That is why to me, Parcel is Sokoban redefined! This is such a wonderful game, a gem amongst gems! I'm surprised that not a lot of people have this in their radar.

Give this game a spin, or to be more accurate, give this game a push. It's got a lot of content that will fill your puzzle game cravings. The graphics, animations, atmosphere, all of it; they are a perfect mix. You will be able to tell that there was a lot of passion that went to this game. You won't regret it unless you have something against the puzzle genre.

Push yourself to buy this game now!

reviewText: Parcel is a game that really deserves much more attention. Seriously, this is a pretty nifty game. It's so simple yet also challenging and the graphics are pretty good for an indie game. I highly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of Portal's companion cube.

reviewText:
Overall: Very good
Difficulty: Medium to High

Likes:
- Every set of puzzles introduces a new character with a new game mechanic, which keeps the game interesting
- Very challenging, especially the later levels
- Pretty satisfying when you complete a puzzle
- Can quick save
- Supports player-created levels

Dislikes:
- Some of the later, more complicated puzzles feel less tightly designed because there are a lot of possible moves that look like they might lead to the solution.  It often ends up being guess-and-check since it is hard to tell if you are headed in the right direction.
- There is a loading screen every time you start or restart a level.  It isn't too long, but it's still annoying, and not something I would expect in a puzzle game.
- I wish there were an undo option (but at least there is a quick save).
- The UI is a bit clunky, particularly switching between characters.
- Sometimes the optional goals are not all achievable in a single attempt, and you will have to replay the level to do them.  For example, sometimes if you go get the glowing orb, then a character or block will end up stuck.  This seems like an odd design decision.

reviewText:
I got this game for a few bucks and will probably play it when I need something puzzly and diffferent for years to come.
It has a ton of levels and is challenging enough to be fun.

If you like puzzle games check it out.
